docs.lead_paragraph: I'VE long been a pack rat when it comes to saving financial documents. I have a file cabinet full of old cellphone and credit card bills, brokerage firm and bank account statements and health insurance benefit forms. When my husband accused me of saving too much, I realized that there wasn't much reasoning behind my recordkeeping. So I decided to find out what financial documents people needed to keep and in what form -- as we fully enter the age of electronic statements -- and what can be purged now.

headline.main: Retain Your Records No Longer Than You Must

docs.abstract: Tips are given on retaining personal financial documents and records; drawings (M)
docs.snippet: I'VE long been a pack rat when it comes to saving financial documents. I have a file cabinet full of old cellphone and credit card bills, brokerage firm and bank account statements and health insurance benefit forms.      When my husband accused me...

docs.lead_paragraph: It was, by all accounts, the most politically volatile amendment proposed to the health care legislation so far: a proposal by Senator Tom Coburn, Republican of Oklahoma, to bar federal health programs and the future federally regulated insurance exchanges from covering the cost of erectile dysfunction medication for convicted sex offenders.

headline.main: Coburn's Erectile Dysfunction Amendment Is Killed

docs.abstract: The amendment would have barred federal health programs and insurance exchanges from covering the cost of erectile dysfunction medication for convicted sex offenders.
docs.snippet: The amendment would have barred federal health programs and insurance exchanges from covering the cost of erectile dysfunction medication for convicted sex offenders.

docs.lead_paragraph: Unfairly or not, the defining images of opposition to health care reform may end up being those rage-filled partisans with spittle on their lips. Whether the outbursts came from inside Congress - the "baby killer" shout of Rep. Randy Neugebauer, and his colleagues who cheered on hecklers - or outside, where protesters hurled vile names against elected representatives, they are powerful and lasting scenes of a democracy gasping for dignity.
docs.abstract: By embracing the Tea Party movement, Republicans are turning into the party of the hissy fit.
docs.snippet: By embracing the Tea Party movement, Republicans are turning into the party of the hissy fit.

docs.lead_paragraph: With millions of jobs disappearing in this recession and more people taking early retirement, Social Security is expected to pay out more in benefits in 2010 than it takes in in payroll taxes, an event that wasn't expected until 2016. This effect may be reversed as the recession eases, but this tipping point reminds us of where things are headed. With more baby boomers retiring, by the end of this decade outlays will exceed revenues every year regardless of the condition of the economy. By 2037, Social Security's surplus, currently at $2.5 trillion, will be exhausted.

headline.main: Simple Steps to Fix Social Security

docs.abstract: Social Security will pay out more in 2010 than it takes in. What should Congress do?
docs.snippet: Social Security will pay out more in 2010 than it takes in. What should Congress do?

docs.lead_paragraph: South Orange Maplewood School District Superintendent Brian Osborne sent a letter to Gov. Christopher J. Christie to address the cuts to state aid for public schools.
docs.abstract: Sjuperintendent Brian Osborne has written to Gov. Chris Christie about the impact of the state's cuts on the South Orange Maplewood School District.
docs.snippet: Sjuperintendent Brian Osborne has written to Gov. Chris Christie about the impact of the state's cuts on the South Orange Maplewood School District.

docs.lead_paragraph: All 18 members of President Obama's bipartisan commission on reducing the national debt have been named now that House Speaker Nancy Pelosi on Wednesday announced three Democratic lawmakers as her choices.

headline.main: Pelosi Names 3 to Obama's Deficit Panel

docs.abstract: The latest appointments to President Obama's deficit reduction panel are Representatives John M. Spratt Jr., Xavier Becerra and Jan Schakowsky.
docs.snippet: The latest appointments to President Obama's deficit reduction panel are Representatives John M. Spratt Jr., Xavier Becerra and Jan Schakowsky.

docs.lead_paragraph: Our colleagues at the Bucks blog have posted an item about an often overlooked aspect of the health care debate: whether the legislation will mean gay couples are taxed on health benefits provided to domestic partners. Read the post. At The New Old Age, the blogger Paula Span reports on the inclusion of a government-run insurance program for long-term care in the final legislation.
docs.abstract: The measure signed by President Obama will not prevent gay couples from being taxed on benefits provided to domestic partners.
docs.snippet: The measure signed by President Obama will not prevent gay couples from being taxed on benefits provided to domestic partners.

docs.lead_paragraph: It has not been easy lately for Republicans and Democrats to find common ground. But Senate leaders in both parties are cringing at the possibility of a last-minute wrinkle in the health care debate: an amendment that would add a public option, or government-run insurance plan, to the budget reconciliation bill now being considered on the Senate floor.
docs.abstract: The public option reappears, and in the unlikeliest place: the Senate.
docs.snippet: The public option reappears, and in the unlikeliest place: the Senate.

docs.lead_paragraph: The health care overhaul package excludes a provision that would have helped same-sex couples: eliminating a tax on employer-provided domestic partner health coverage.

headline.main: Gays May Still Pay More for Health Coverage

docs.abstract: The plan to overhaul the health care system would not eliminate the extra tax levied on domestic partner benefits.
docs.snippet: The plan to overhaul the health care system would not eliminate the extra tax levied on domestic partner benefits.

docs.lead_paragraph: Yes, the executive order that Stupak accepted as cover for his pivotal health care vote is probably meaningless. And yes, the health care bill, as passed, effectively tilts public policy in a more pro-choice direction: The fact that women are required to write a separate check for abortion coverage means that public money isn't literally paying for abortion, but it doesn't change the fact that federal dollars are being spent in ways that make it much easier to obtain abortion-covering insurance. (And that's without getting into the tangled issue of community health centers.) But what struck me most, at the end, wasn't the folly of Stupak's decision to compromise his pro-life principles by voting "yes," but the extraordinary loneliness of his position before he folded.
docs.abstract: The loneliness of the pro-life Democrat.
docs.snippet: The loneliness of the pro-life Democrat.
